thread.title: Watchdog keeps eye on comparison sites
thread.title_full: Watchdog keeps eye on comparison sites

author: news.com.au
title: Watchdog keeps eye on comparison sites
text:
FROM home loans to hotel rooms, there's plenty of comparison websites promising to point us to the best deals on just about everything.
SO it's handy that the consumer watchdog, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, his issued tips to help get the best outcome when using the sites.
The ACCC has released both consumer and industry guidance on the operation and use of comparison websites. "Comparator websites can drive competition and assist consumers to make informed purchasing decisions when comparing what are often quite complex products," says ACCC deputy chair Delia Rickard. "However, the ACCC is concerned that poor conduct by some industry participants can mislead consumers." The ACCC's tips for consumers include: *Make sure you know what is being compared - each site may not compare all offers out there - use a number of sites *Understand commercial relationships - the sites may receive financial inducements to promote products *Know what your needs are - when searching, consider ranking by "benefits" or "value" rather than just by "price" The industry guidance sets out how industry can comply with competition and consumer protection laws, including setting out three guiding principles: *Facilitating honest, like-for-like comparisons *Being transparent about commercial relationships *Clearly disclosing who and what is being compared Ms Rickard said operators should carefully read the guidance as there will be no excuse for non-compliance with Australian consumer laws. The ACCC recently found a number of websites, in particular those comparing energy plans, included information that may mislead consumers about the extent of the comparison service, the amount of savings that could be achieved and the impartiality of the comparisons. Following contact by the ACCC, website operators quickly implemented appropriate changes to remove or amend the potentially misleading information. The ACCC has previously won more than $2 million in penalties against comparison website EnergyWatch for misleading advertising, and more than $10,000 from Comparethemarket in relation to claims it made about its health insurance service. After the release of the guidelines, Comparethemarket chief executive Matt McCann said his company would use them to provide "clarity around the most ethical approach". "It is now incumbent upon the industry to adopt these guidelines as a minimum, or to take the responsibility to do even more to ensure consumers continue to get the best outcomes when using comparator services," he said. The ACCC's guidance is available on its website.
